<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/51  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates stationary sound waves in cylindrical tubes. Fig. 1.1 shows a stationary wave pattern in a tube which is open at both ends.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 112, 692, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 278, 532, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 920, 344]]<|/det|>
The tube has length \(L\) and diameter \(d\). The frequency of the sound for the stationary wave pattern shown is \(f\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 356, 510, 374]]<|/det|>
There are a number of different tubes available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 387, 564, 405]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(f\) and \(d\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 413, 551, 441]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\nu}{f} = 2L + kd\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 576, 466]]<|/det|>
where \(\nu\) is the speed of sound in air and \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 479, 707, 497]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(f\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 495, 707, 513]]<|/det|>
Explain how your results could be used to determine values for \(k\) and \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 526, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 574, 395, 592]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 603, 410, 621]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 633, 346, 650]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 662, 351, 679]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 691, 447, 708]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 789, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the discharge of a capacitor in the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 100, 623, 310]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 327, 533, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 358, 588, 377]]<|/det|>
The student closes the switch and charges the capacitor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
The switch is opened and a stop-watch is started. The capacitor discharges through the two resistors of resistance \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) connected between P and Q. At a fixed time \(t\) the potential difference \(V\) across the capacitor is measured.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 620, 471]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for different values of \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 483, 615, 501]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(V, R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 510, 589, 546]]<|/det|>
\[\ln \Bigl (\frac{V}{E}\Bigr) = -\frac{t}{C(R_1 + R_2)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 920, 576]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery and \(C\) is the capacitance of the capacitor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 146, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 587, 720, 606]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\ln V\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{R_1 + R_2}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 618, 611, 636]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 790, 917, 808]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 821, 917, 839]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 836, 920, 855]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 574, 91]]<|/det|> Values of \(R_{1}, R_{2}, V\) and \(\ln V\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 655, 121]]<|/det|> Each resistance value has a percentage uncertainty of \(\pm 5\%\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 134, 541, 152]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 163, 885, 465]]<|/det|>
\(R_{1}/\mathrm {k}\Omega\)\(R_{2}/\mathrm {k}\Omega\)\((R_{1}+R_{2})/\mathrm {k}\Omega\)\(\frac {1}{R_{1}+R_{2}}/10^{-6}\Omega ^{-1}\)\(V/V\)\(\ln (V/V)\)
22331.280.247
22471.980.683
22682.871.054
33472.390.871
33683.281.188
47683.551.267
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 816, 515]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \((R_{1} + R_{2}) / \mathrm{k}\Omega\) and \(\frac{1}{R_{1} + R_{2}} / 10^{-6}\Omega^{-1}\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 529, 650, 562]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \((R_{1} + R_{2})\) and \(\frac{1}{R_{1} + R_{2}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 537, 920, 556]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 584, 144, 603]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 583, 176, 602]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 577, 609, 609]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\ln (V / V)\) against \(\frac{1}{R_{1} + R_{2}} / 10^{-6}\Omega^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 610, 448, 640]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \(\frac{1}{R_{1} + R_{2}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 616, 920, 635]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 181, 663]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 643, 920, 680]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 662, 920, 681]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 692, 181, 711]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 691, 920, 725]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 895, 920, 914]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 210, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
\[y\mathrm{-intercept} = .................................................... [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 242, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 242, 185, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(C\) and \(E\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 351, 306]]<|/det|>
Data: \(t = (60 \pm 1) \text{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 443, 917, 460]]<|/det|>
<form>C = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 473, 920, 491]]<|/det|>
<form>E = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 181, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 551, 537]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 664, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[918, 664, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 695, 146, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 694, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated using the same capacitor. Determine the value of \((R_{1} + R_{2})\) that would give a value of \(V\) of \(5.0 \text{V}\) at time \(t = 60 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 845, 920, 864]]<|/det|>
\[(R_{1} + R_{2}) = ............................................................ \Omega \quad [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 878, 920, 895]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 15]
